The jeep slows at a fence gate, by a sign reading: CAC US Authorized Personnel Only. MAN (V.O.) (cont'd) ...and men to guard them. A SOLDIER steps out of the gate hut, sees the driver of t jeep and salutes. The jeep rolls through. MAN (V.0.) (cont'd) Castle walls have always held high ground positions to fire from... A GUNMAN stands in a GUNTOWER, high-powered rifle in his arms. MAN (V.0.) (cont'd) ..-and places to run a flag. The first orange light of the day reaches the roof of the Administration Building. SOLDIERS in crisp, practiced mov unfold a FLAG, hook it to a line and pull it up a flagpol MAN (V.O.) (cont'd) The only difference between this castle and the countless others built over the last 8,000 years is that they were built to keep people out. Karen Goldberg

dialogues.text: This castle was built to keep people in. A_horn sounds, the cell doors all slide open and the men step out, clutching towels and toothbrushes. They all sto in unison. A VOICE barks out a command, the men turn on their heels and walk. EXT. OFFICERS’ PARKING LOT - DAWN 3 The jeep drives up. The door cpens and out gets COLONEL WINTER, 48, the Commandant of the USDB. You could cut woo with the crease on his pants. He looks up at the flag and the soldiers on the roof. The soldiers salute the flag, turn on their heels. dialogues.text: Lieutenant. Winter returns salute. Peretz hands him a cup of coffee a they walk. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) How are we this morning?

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: (off his clipboard) 813 in general population, 3 in the hospital and 2 in Pc. They turn and head up the stairs. Karen Goldberg

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ

dialogues.text: One other thing, sir. The Hispanic inmates are complaining they’re receiving smaller portions than the black inmates in the mess. They feel it’s due to the predominance of black inmates on food service detail. Winter shakes his head as he looks out at the inmates in Yard.

dialogues.text: Another matter of life and death. (beat) Get me their duty roster.

dialogues.text: The fuck you doing, taco?

dialogues.text: M-m-my d-d-dad was a m-m-mason--

dialogues.text: Fifty yards away, THUMPER and MIGUEL are circling each ot cheered on by a circle of men.

dialogues.speaker: MIGUEL
dialogues.text: You fucks serve us up portions the size of pigeon shit, and now you got a problem?

dialogues.text: If you think about it, this is really an interesting example of stimulus and response. (off Peretz’s look) No matter what stimulus we create, the response is always the same. It always ends up in the Yard. Different actors in different parts, of course, but the basic play doesn’t vary much. Someone should write a paper on it. Peretz nods. Down below, Thumper moves toward Miguel. Per raises his radio. Winter motions him to hold up. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) Wait for it... Thumper pushes Miguel. Winter motions Peretz to go ahead. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) No one in or out; hospital squad in reserve. Peretz speaks into his radio.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: Lock down all sally ports. §& Company ist Platoon 2nd squad into reserve.

dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg

dialogues.text: Yes. Go. Jinx hurries off. THUMPER and MIGUEL circle each other. Miguel pulls a shiv Someone tosses Thumper a five-pound weight tied to a leng of rope. Dellwo and Cyrus turn.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: Fuck you and your house. Three on the brothers.

WINTER‘S OFFICE - DAY 10 Winter winces at the sight of the black inmate crumpling the ground.

dialogues.text: Yates takes down some more bets. Cyrus steps up to him.

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: As much as I disapprove of the entire business... do you have to bet the side?

dialogues.text: Nope. Pick your dog.

dialogues.text: Main event. Thumper and Miguel. The large fellow for two. Straight up. Yates looks over at Thumper and Miguel, still circling.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: You're on. Cyrus nods. Not a second later, Miguel darts in, slashes Thumper across the chest. Thumper howls. Cyrus frowns. Yates shrugs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  a1 12 13 CONTINUED: il YATES (cont'd) (scribbles in book, mutters) Cyrus... owes me two.

dialogues.text: It's not over yet, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: You hang onto that optimism, Cyrus. It works for you. Anyone else? Thumper charges forward, swings the weight low, into the side of Miguel's knee with a horrible crunch. Miguel goes down screaming. Cyrus looks at Yates. Yates frowns. YATES (cont'd) Like you said, it's not over yet. Thumper gets the weight swinging again, high over his hea Just then, the rope snaps. dialogues.text: Sarge! Look out! McLaren starts to turn. The weight slams into his back, knocking him off his feet. INT. WINTER’S OFFICE - DAY 12 Winter's face goes very dark.

dialogues.text: End it. Peretz raises his radio.

17 Sir, they just announced the verdict. Winter arches an eyebrow. LT. PERETZ (cont'd) Guilty. Winter sighs, shakes his head.

dialogues.text: I can’t believe they actually went through with it. (beat) When does he arrive? Peretz hands Winter the fax. Winter is stunned. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: _ DUFFY

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Hutus.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Hutus. Fuck.

dialogues.text: You don’t think he should’ve been convicted?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: No one does. Not even the men who convicted him. They wanted to keep it in house. But once the story hit the New York Times, they had no choice. They couldn’t let it slide. Dellwo strains to get a look out the window. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I know what you're wondering: Do you salute me; do I salute you? No to both. My men salute me, of course, and each other, according to rank, but there’s no saluting by the population. Irwin nods. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) Hungry?

That long, low building over there is where the workshops and the laundry are. Winter notices Irwin looking at the old, half broken-down stone wall in the middle of the Yard. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) That's the old blockhouse wall. It’s all that remains of the original building where the first prisoners stayed, back in the 1870's. We noticed the wall was leaning earlier this year, so I asked the men to take it down, rebuild the foundation, put it back up. They enjoy working on it; gives them something to do. dialogues.text: Three years ago, in Bosnia, I was driving through an IFOR town, and I saw an old man sitting on the steps of his house with a child I presume was his grandson, playing dominces, and I had a revelation. All my life in the Army, through good wars and bad, I'd been doing my best to make dangerous parts of the world safe enough so old men could sit on their steps and play games with their grandchildren. It was not entirely selfless, of course. I loved the work with all my heart. I gave a great deal for it. I lost a wife due to neglect. J am a stranger to my daughter. I have a grandson I have never met. (beat) When I saw that old man in Bosnia, I didn’t begrudge him his game with his grandson. I simply thought, “My turn.” Now, I didn’t retire after Bosnia. I should have, but I didn’t. I took one last assignment. To Burundi. And here I am. (beat) I'm done, gentlemen. I’m not fighting anyone or anything ever again. I’m going to do my time, then I’m going to go home, and, God willing, sit on my front steps and play a game of dominoes with my grandson. And with that, Irwin walks out. dialogues.text: Yes, Lieutenant?!

dialogues.text: Sir, those are different men. Winter looks closer and he can't believe his eyes. There' no Dellwo, no Duffy -- no one we recognize. Winter thinks. Hmm. Exhales.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Release Aguilar and the other men on lockdown. Peretz nods. COLONEL WINTER (cont 'd) Then bring him to me.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: Who, sir?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: The Prince of Fucking Venezuela. Who do you think?

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: General Irwin?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: (glowering) Mister Irwin. Peretz nods, turns on his heel. Karen Goldberg  78 79 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aguilar and the other fifty men who’d been in lockdown wa out onto the Yard. As they approach the almost-finished blockhouse wall, the men already there start clapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter stands at his window, looking down at Aguilar and others by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: It’s sad, but they just don’t get it, do they? Apparently the irony of prisoners building their own prisons escapes them.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL . IRWIN
dialogues.text: No, they get it. Winter turns. Irwin is standing in the middle of the room GENERAL IRWIN (cont'd) They just don’t care. It gives them something to do. Winter stares at Irwin for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Irwin, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I want to do my time and go home.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: So you say, and yet everything you've done here contradicts that. (beat) What do you want for them? The ability to salute, use rank? What?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I think I want the same thing you do -- that they should be better men going out of here than they were coming ain,

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: That’s the line my predecessor used. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  79

79 COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) In his last two years here, there were seven escape attempts and twelve injury assaults on an officer, including one killed. In the ten years_since I assumed command, there have been zero escape attempts, zero injury assaults, zero officer fatalities. Some may question my ways, Mr. Irwin, but they work. (beat) See, in case you've forgotten, those men down there are not here for unpaid parking tickets and library fines. Mr. Beaupre and his cronies raped and murdered a young woman in a parking lot in Manila. Mr. Dellwo robbed a PX with a shotgun, blew a poor corporal’s hand off. Your beloved Mr. Aguilar almost killed an MP with a claw hammer.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I labor under no illusions about what these men have done. I just think they could occasionally be reminded of the best thing they did in'their lives rather than having to only think of the worst. Winter looks at Irwin. He walks over to his display cases looks over his collection.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: I know you don’t respect me, Mr. Irwin.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: You the great front line combat veteran. Me the rear echeion jailer bureaucrat who collects grisly mementos of war, but has never actually set foot on a battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I don't-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  79 80 61.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: This ig combat, Mr. Irwin. This is war. and it’s a war I’ve been fighting for a_ long time. My men and I are vastly outnumbered and we spend every day behind enemy lines. Because make no mistake about it... (points out window) ...they are the enemy; you are the enemy, and I will not have any terms dictated to me by the enemy. There will be no saluting in any form whatsoever. There will be no sneaking around the prohibition of rank, I don’t care what words you use. And, as it seems to have become a focus of much tension and turmoil... (checks his watch) ...in a couple of minutes, there will be no wall. Irwin doesn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aguilar and the men are standing back, enjoying a look at the completed wall. Cyrus shakes his head. Aguilar looks at him -- what?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've never quite understood. It goes nowhere, encloses nothing, doesn't support anything. It’s... it’s just a wall.

dialogues.speaker: AGUILAR
dialogues.text: Yeah. But it’s our wall. Cyrus grins, nods. And then they hear a sound and turn.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUCK GATES
dialogues.text: Are opening across the Yard. Everyone looks. They hear a rattling rumble and then...

dialogues.speaker: A BULLDOZER
dialogues.text: Comes through the open gates. It heads for the men and th blockhouse wall. No one knows what to make of it. And the TWO DOZEN GUARDS, including Niebolt and McLaren, run out, flank the bulldozer, batons ready. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  80 el 82 83 62.

dialogues.speaker: MCLAREN
dialogues.text: Move away from the wall! Now the inmates realize what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: AGUILAR
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: MCLAREN
dialogues.text: Move away from the wall! The men boo, jeer, but move back from the advancing guard Aguilar doesn’t back away. He starts walking toward the bulldozer. MCLAREN (cont'd) Don't do it, Aguilar! But Aguilar doesn’t stop. Niebolt runs out, grabs Aguilar

dialogues.speaker: NIEBOLT
dialogues.text: Don’t! Aguilar pushes Niebolt away. A ripple of fear goes through the men. INT. WINTER’S OFFICE - DAY 81 Winter, Irwin and Peretz are at the window.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: End it. Peretz nods, clicks on his radio. Winter almost grins. Irwin gets a very bad feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whistle blows. The inmates hit the dirt, covering their heads with their arms. Aguilar walks in.front of the bulldozer, raises his arms.

dialogues.speaker: NIEBOLT
dialogues.text: Get down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin looks down in horror, realizing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  83 84 85 63.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: For Godsake, get down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aguilar stands in the path of the advancing bulldozer. Th bulldozer slows, stops. Aguilar grins, starts to turn to look back at the others. CRACKCRACKCRACK. Aguilar jerks from three bullet hits to the chest. He looks surprised more than pained. He falls face forward to the ground. Silence for a moment. Aguilar doesn’t move. And then dark wet stains start to blossom on his back.

dialogues.speaker: NIEBOLT
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck... Doc! boc Sir, permission to examine the prisoner, sir!

dialogues.speaker: MCLAREN
dialogues.text: Go! Doc scrambles to Aguilar, rolls him over and we see the t cloth o£ the bullet strikes and his dog tags, covered in blood. boc Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter looks at Irwin with an expression that says “see w you made me do?”

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: They should only be using rubber bullets. I can’t imagine how something like this could happen. (to Peretz) Look into it, Lieutenant. I/’11 expect a full report on my desk by Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Escort the prisoner back to his cell. Standard seventy-two hour lockdown for the population. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  85 86 87 88 89 90 64.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Peretz heads out. Irwin goes with him. He looks back at Winter, stunned, now fully seeing the depth of Winter's darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF DISSOLVES shows the men sitting out the 72 ho lockdown. At first, they yell and bang their cell doors. But as day becomes night becomes day again, they quiet do take their meals, sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A_horn sounds and all the cell doors slide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light rain falls. The blockhouse wall is gone. The only sign it was ever there is a strip of new earth where the foundation was dug out. 300 inmates are in the Yard, scattered across it, back to their racial divisions. The mood is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter looks down from his window, Peretz by his side.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: And once more, order returns to the jungle. Winter turns and goes to his desk. Peretz stays by the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Irwin walks out alone to the center of the Yard, where the biockhouse wall had been. He looks at the strip of new earth for a few moments, then he turns to the men behind him.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Dellwo.

dialogues.speaker: TEN-HUT
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  90 91 92 6s.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At that, the 300 men scattered randomly across the Yard m and start to form a grid. Even BEAUPRE and HIS MEN step into line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peretz looks down at the grid as it forms, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: Sir...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grid forms up into crisp, even lines, filling half th Yard. The men stand at attention. Irwin nods to Doc. Doc steps out of line, walks up to Irw holds out his hand. In his hand are DOG TAGS, smeared wit dark, dry blood. Irwin takes them. Doc returns to his lin Irwin kneels, scoops up some dirt with his hand and burie the tags. He pats the earth flat, stands. He looks out at the men.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Some might think to be remembered in this way would be a disgrace to a soldier, but there is no disgrace in this. The greatest monuments to our fallen heroes are not made of marble. They're deep in the jungle -- a rifle driven into the ground, a helmet perched atop it, some dog tags. (beat) And that is the kind of tribute this man has earned. He doesn't get a twenty-one gun salute or any of the other honors usually bestowed upon a soldier. He gets more. (beat) He goes to meet his maker with the honor he claimed for himself. (beat) Gentlemen -- Private First Class Ramon Aguilar, United States Marine Corps. Irwin bows his head and places his hand over his heart. THE THREE HUNDRED MEN follow suit. Someone in the group starts singing the Marine hymn. A few others join in. Karen Goldberg  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter and Peretz look down from the window.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: A martyr. He's made the stuttering monkey into a martyr. And then they start to hear it -- the Marine hymn, swelli COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) Sound the dinner horn.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: It's not for another ten--

dialogues.speaker: SOUND IT
dialogues.text: Peretz snaps up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred men are singing, and they are singing loud. And then the horn sounds, cutting through their voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horn dies. Silence -- no singing. Winter exhales in relief -- that's better. He's about to turn away from the window when... THE THREE HUNDRED MEN turn as one and salute him. Winter grimaces, does not return the salute. The men drop their salute and march off toward the Tiers.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Bring General Irwin to me.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: (beat) Mister Irwin... Winter turns and glares at Peretz -- do not fuck with me. Peretz nods and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin sits across from Winter. After some silence... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goidberg  96

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: If the inmates could confine themselves to a simple hand motion such as this... {runs hand through hair) ...I don't see any problem. It's — not technically a salute, and as long as no one outside of the USDB knows about it, we can live with it. All right?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: (beat) I don't think that really matters now.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: All right. I just thought--

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: In fact, Colonel, there's only one thing the men want anymore.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: And that is...?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Your resignation.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: They don't want better food. They don't want more TV. They don't even want out. They just want you to go away. Winter looks at Irwin for a moment, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Peretz!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I agree with them. You should go. But not because of the brutality you encourage. Not even because you have men killed. You should go because you are the very worst kind of officer. You’re a disgrace to the uniform. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  96 97 98 68.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The door opens; Peretz appears.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Escort the prisoner back to his cell. Peretz nods, gestures to the door for Irwin. Irwin locks eyes with Winter, then walks out. Peretz follows him. Winter just sits there for a moment, thinking. He reaches over and taps his intercom button. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) Marjorie, get General Wheeler on the line.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Colonel, I’m sure he’s left for the day--

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Then get him at home. Winter sits back, looking out at the Yard, playing with something in his hands. He locks down and sees that it’s same old bayonet again. Winter looks at it. His phone buzzes. Winter drops the bayonet on his desk and picks up the phone. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) {into phone) Good evening, General. Sorry to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McLaren is on the floor, reading from a list of names.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MCLAREN
dialogues.text: Fenton, Fiengold, Garbowski...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE 6TH TIER 98
dialogues.text: Irwin is sitting in his cell, reading.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MCLAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...Hadley, Hammerman, Irwin, Jankelford... Irwin looks up, surprised. Karen Goldberg  99 100 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin walks in. Niebolt directs him.

dialogues.speaker: PVT. NIEBOLT
dialogues.text: Number three. Irwin walks down the row of phones. He’s surprised to see who's waiting for him -- a young officer -- LT. DAVES. Ir sits, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LT. DAVES
dialogues.text: Hello, Leland. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Frankly, Lieutenant, I'm feeling a little confused. I’m trying to figure out what possible reason my lawyer could have for being here.

dialogues.speaker: LT. DAVES
dialogues.text: You don’t know? They haven't told you? Irwin doesn’t know what Daves is talking about. LT, DAVES (cont'd) Leland -- you're being released. Irwin is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyrus is at a table with Dellwo, Duffy, Doc and Enriquez. boc It’s called a compassionate release. They're saying he has health problems--

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: That's bullshit! boc I'm just saying what they're saying. . (to all) They're keeping him in p.c. tonight. He gets out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Kill the head and the body will die. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  70.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: It's an old line. It means--

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: I know what it means, Cyrus. It's just bullshit, is all. They remove this head and this body is just gonna get stronger. We're gonna go apeshit on this place. boc No, we're not.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: Like fuck we're not.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIQUEZ
dialogues.text: Who's gonna lead us?

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: I don't know... Me. Eyebrows arch at that. DELLWO (cont'd) You then. JI don't care.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIQUEZ
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: Somebody . There're no volunteers. The table goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: YATES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's perfect! Absolutely goddamn perfect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yates is standing ‘outside Irwin's cell door. Irwin is in sitting on the bunk, in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: It makes so much sense when you think about it, it’s almost obvious. But I didn’t see it. Nobody did. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  101
“102 YATES (cont'd) Maybe Winter did. Maybe he knew. But there was nothing he could do.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, Yates?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Oh, give it up, you old dog! Come on! It fits perfectly. You're a smart man, right? A three-star general. Brilliant strategist. One of the best ever. Wrote books on the stuff. And you wanna tell me you weren't planning this right from the beginning? This is what you wanted, isn’t it, Chief? You serve two months -- two months and you’re out of here! You're a genius! You got everyone to play their little parts -- and they played ‘em perfectly. Even me.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MCLAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yates! Time's up!

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: (to McLaren) Okay! (to Irwin) Just tell me the truth. I promise I won’t tell a soul. I'm right, aren’t

dialogues.speaker: MCLAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Move it, Yates!

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: I’m moving! I'm moving! (to Irwin) come on. I don’t care. I’m your biggest fan. Just tell me. You knew if you kept at Winter long enough he'd let you go just to get rid of you, right? Irwin says nothing. Yates starts off.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: It occurred to me, yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  101 102 103 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Yates is hit by that, stops. For all his boisterous cynic he's disappointed. But he hides it.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: God bless you, Mister. You are the king.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. MCLAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Yates, don’t make me come down there!

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: I’m walking! One foot in front of the other! Yates heads off down the hall toward the sally port. Irwin sits on his bed, staring into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peretz and McLaren walk with Irwin, now in street clothes down a hallway. He glances out a window. HIS POV down into the Yard. Empty. Not a soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin comes out with Peretz and McLaren. They walk toward the inner fence gate, 50 yards off. There are two more ga past that. Beyond the outer gate there are TEN TV NEWSVAN waiting. WINTER and LT. DAVES wait by the inner gate. Irwin, Peretz and McLaren walk up to Winter.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Irwin, I'm going to say to you what I say to everyone who leaves this facility: Irwin sees something over Winter's shoulder. IN THE FIVE WINDOWS OF THE LIBRARY stand Dellwo, Duffy, Enriquez and Beaupre, saluting. Irwin's eyes glide over them to-the fifth window, where... YATES is standing. He’s not saluting. He’s just standing and staring. He and Irwin lock eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  103 104 73.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) I hope you can make good use of the time you have left to you, and I... Winter senses Irwin’s looking at something, turns to look As he turns, Dellwo and the others lower their hands. Winter turns back to Irwin. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) ...and I hope that you can live in such a way that you never have to see the inside of a place like this again. Winter sticks out his hand. Irwin shakes it. Winter nods. Irwin starts off. There’s an odd expression on his face - one we’ve seen before. He looks pissed off. Like he doesn want to do what he knows he must. He sighs, stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Colonel, may I ask one question before I go?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Of course. Irwin walks back to the Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: What I’d like to know is-- Irwin suddenly hauls off and clocks Winter with a roundho right. Winter sails back, hits the ground, blood streamin from his nose. GENERAL IRWIN (cont‘d) (cont'd) --did you really think you could get rid of me that easily? Peretz and McLaren are on Irwin in a flash, wailing with their batons. Irwin covers up and drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dellwo and the rest look at each for a moment -- did that really happen? -- then erupt in cheers. Karen Goldberg  74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin is dragged back toward the entrance, blood dripping from his head. He sees... Dellwo and the others in the library windows, jumping up down, cheering. And then there’s... Yates. He gives the smallest of grins. Irwin looks at Yates as Peretz and McLaren drag him insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin lays on the bunk. He hears footsteps approach.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSTEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Meal! The meal slot slides open and a tray. is pushed in. Irwin takes it. TRUSTEE (0.8.) (cont'd) You have three minutes to eat your meal. Irwin looks at the meal. There’s something hidden underne the napkin. He picks it up, sees a Ziploc bag full of som cloudy liquid. He picks it up, opens it, takes a whiff. His eyes water.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Cyrus? 107 INT. THE HOLE - OUTSIDE IRWIN’S CELL - NIGHT - CROSSC Cyrus wears a trustee’s orange vest, pushes the meal cart

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: You found it.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: What in God's name is it?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Pruno. Original recipe. I thought you might be in some pain. It’1ll take the edge off. Just don’t get any on your skin. (loud) Two minutes and thirty seconds! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Funny you should ask that. A few of us are wondering what in the hell you're doing here.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: (beat) I don’t know. I’ve been asking myself the same thing. Aguilar, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I can’t help feeling responsible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? His death? There's only one man responsible for that and it’s not you. You are, however, responsible for making him feel like a soldier again. (beat) As it happens, I know several hundred other men who would like nothing More than to feel like soldiers again themselves. (loud) Two minutes!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: To what end?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: You know what end. Unless you don’t think it’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: {beat) No, it’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Do you see any other option?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: There are always other options.

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Such as? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  107 108 109 110 76.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Irwin has no answer. CYRUS (cont'd) The men are waiting, General. gust give the word. Irwin shuts his eyes, thinking hard. He grins ruefully to himself, shakes his head, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Has General Wheeler paid a visit yet?

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: No. (loud) One minute!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: He will. Probably tomorrow. Which means you'll have to move quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three car MOTORCADE -- two jeeps and a sedan -- approac the prison, small CAC (Combined Arms Center) flags whippi from the antennas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorcade drives through the last of the fence gates into the parking lot and stops. A CORPORAL hustles from t jeep and opens the rear passenger door. Out gets... LT. GEN. JAMES WHEELER, 50, none too happy to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler is in with Winter.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: It was on all the news shows, Ed! Sure, it's hazy telephoto and they had to put one of those circles around it to highlight it, but it's pretty damn clear what happened -- Lee Irwin decked you!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: It was really more of a slap, sir-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: That was a helluva slap! You landed on your ass! Now, what in God's name is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, sir. I’m not a doctor. He-- Two weeks ago I observed him marching a man back and forth in the Yard. A minor eccentricity. Fine. Since then, it’s as if he’s been doing everything he can to provoke me, in order to recruit a following. It's almost as if -- and again, I'm not a doctor -- but it’s as if in some way he believed he were still in the field, commanding a division.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Are you saying he’s delusional?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: I’m just telling you what I've seen.

dialogues.text: Diefenbaker. (looks at Winter) He’s a pilot. Winter's eyes go wide. He clicks on his radio.

dialogues.text: It's rising... {to McClintock and others) Get down! Now! McClintock and the others start climbing down, but the helicopter is climbing faster than they can descend. Irwin turns, sees... YATES, sprinting toward the helicopter. dialogues.text: {into phone) Well, Lee, I see you've been busy.

dialogues.text: You said I should take up a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: I was thinking more along the lines of woodworking.

dialogues.text: Have you spoken to Colonel Winter yet?

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I’m sure he told you we're planning amass escape or some such nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: . LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.text: You know why we did this. He has to go, Jim. He can't stay.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: You won't get any argument from me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: We don't need any public announcement -- we don't want to embarrass anyone. All I need is your word that he's gone -- soon.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN, WHEELER
dialogues.text: How would first light be?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: That would be fine. (beat) The only other thing I need is a written guarantee that the men involved won't receive any additional time.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: That's a bit stickier, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: It's not negotiable.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not comfortable doing this over the phone. How about you come out here with some proposals and we'll hash them out.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: How stupid do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: A man’s got to try. (beat) How about someone else? There's gotta be someone you'd trust -- someone who could make sure I don't try to slip one by you. Irwin looks over his men, eyes settling on YATES.

dialogues.speaker: YATES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin and Yates are off by themselves. Yates is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: What about Cyrus? He's a helluva lot smarter than I am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  130.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: He never studied to be a lawyer.

dialogues.text: Oh, Christ, is that it? I'm going to have to carry that burden for the rest of my life? Irwin nods. Yates sighs, shakes his head. BINOCULAR POV of Yates and Irwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter is watching Yates and Irwin through the binoculars

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Yates. How... appropriate.

dialogues.text: Most of the inmates are asleep. The few that are awake sa Irwin and Yates as they walk through. As they reach the truck gate, Irwin nods to Cutbush and Thumper. They pull the huge doors open a crack. Yates hea for the opening.

dialogues.text: Don't make any sudden moves out there. (Yates stops) Some of the best sharpshooters in the world are going to have an "x" on your forehead and they’ve been drinking a lot of coffee. Yates gives him a look, then steps out between the doors.

dialogues.text: General, sir. Mr. Yates. Wheeler looks up, lets the plans roll up as Yates is brou forward.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr. Yates. Jim Wheeler. He extends a hand. Yates shakes it. LT. GEN. WHEELER (cont'd) Can I get you anything? Coffee, soda? Something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: How's Lee Irwin holding up?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Of course he is. He's a hardy son of bitch. Yates nods. Silence. LT. GEN. WHEELER (cont'd) To business then. Have a seat. Yates sits. Wheeler sits across from him. LT. GEN. dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg

dialogues.text: Oh, come on...

dialogues.text: If you don't do what I ask, you're personally going to get an additional five years. dialogues.text: We've got hostages in there--

dialogues.text: No, you don’t. Every man who accepts duty at USDB knows the score. We don't negotiate for the release of hostages. (beat) We will retake the Castle. Colonel Winter will remain in command. We will not be dictated to by prisoners. Ever.

dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: First, I just want you to take a moment to think about what I’ve said. And while you're thinking, there's someone I want you to talk to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  261 133.

dialogues.text: Wheeler nods to a corporal. Yates is puzzled. His puzzlem grows as the corporal returns, escorting a WOMAN into the light. It’s JILL, Yates’ wife. LT. GEN. WHEELER (cont'd) Excuse me. dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: What're you doing here?

dialogues.text: I was driving by, saw the lights... What do you think I’m doing here? They woke me up about thirty minutes ago, said there was trouble.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: I can’t fucking believe it.

dialogues.text: Did you take over the prison?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Not me personally.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You _t 2 ison?

dialogues.text: Did they say why they wanted you here?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: No. They just said you were in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: They got that right.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Richard? Why am I here?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: They want me to do something. And they figure seeing you will convince me to go along. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  134.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: YATES (cont'd) (looks at her) If I do what they want, I get out this morning.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (excited) You’re serious? This morning?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: You care?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Don't make me hit you. Just because you've been an asshole every time I've come out to see you doesn’t mean I don’t still love you. They look at each other for a long beat. Yates shakes his head, turns away. JILL (cont'd) What happens if you don’t help them?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: I get another five years.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Not just me. Everyone’ll get more time. And some men will die.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What do they want you to do?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: (beat) I don’t know. (looks back at Castle) God, I wish he’d picked someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yates walks back through the fence gates, looking numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors are open a crack. Yates slips through. The door are shut behind him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  263 264 135.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Well? Close on Yates. He thinks... nods.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: All set. Dellwo, Doc, Cyrus, Enriquez, Thumper, Cutbush cheer. Cla each other on the back, embrace.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIQUEZ
dialogues.text: Wanna tell the men?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Let them sleep.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: One thing: Wheeler wants me and you to wait with Winter on the roof of the Administration Building at first light. A chopper’s gonna remove him.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: A chopper?! No way! He ain't flying outta here! He's gotta walk out! Right through the middle of everyone yelling at him!

dialogues.speaker: CYRUS
dialogues.text: Or, better yet, saying nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: Ooh, yeah. That’d be cool.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: (firm) He's going out on a chopper. Everyone quiets. Irwin thinks, looks around, nods -- let' do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin, Yates, Dellwo, Cyrus and Enriquez move through the sleeping men. Some are awake, starting fires. They nod to Irwin, salute. Yates is doing his best to hide his torment. Dellwo pats his shoulder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  264 265 266 267 136. CONTINUED: “264

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: Glad to have you with us, Pilot. Some folks thought once you got beyond the fence you weren't coming back. Yates forces a grin, but he's dying inside. They reach the doors to the Administration Building. Pere opens the doors from the inside. Irwin and Yates step inside. The doors shut behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office has been thrashed -- by trebuchet, fire and wa Winter stands by the shattered window, looking down at th men in the Yard and out to the brightening eastern sky. He’s holding the folded FLAG in his hands. Peretz enters.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ
dialogues.text: Colonel, they're here. Winter nods, takes a last look out the window, sets the f down on his desk and starts across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin and Yates are waiting as Winter comes out of his of with Peretz. Winter doesn't even look at Irwin. He heads through a door to a stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter and Peretz lead Yates and Irwin up the stairs. Yat is in hell. Winter is the first to reach the top of the stairs. He hi the pushbar and goes out onto the roof. Peretz is right behind him. As soon as Peretz goes through the door, Yates grabs the pushbar and yanks it back, shutting the door.

dialogues.speaker: . LT. PERETZ, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Hey! What're you deing? They can hear Peretz pulling at the door, but it's locked from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Good question, What are you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  137.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Wheeler’s not gonna take Winter out of here -- he’s gonna take you.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: (beat) I know.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: What? What do you mean you know? Irwin says nothing. YATES (cont'd) (gets a weird feeling) You planned it?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: (beat, smiles sympathetically) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh, my God. Of course. You knew Wheeler wouldn’t negotiate. You knew he’d want to take you out and you wanted it to go this way, instead of by force. That's why you picked me to be the messenger. You knew Wheeler would make me an offer. If you'd picked Cyrus... Cyrus would’ve told Wheeler to go fuck himself. But me? You knew I'd go along. Didn’t you.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: (beat) The thought had occurred to me.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: . GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: What didn’t occur to me is that you might not go through with it.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Disappoint me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  138.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Irwin shakes his head. He and Yates share a look.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Then Winter is going to stay.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Which means we lose. Irwin doesn’t say anything, thinking. YATES (cont'd) Then why did we fight?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: You don’t only fight when you know you're going to win. Irwin moves to the door. Yates stops him. GENERAL IRWIN (cont'd) Captain, if I don’t get out there in thirty seconds, they will take this facility by force and many of our good friends will die.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: There’s got to be another way. Irwin looks at him, says nothing. YATES (cont'd) Come on! That’s what you're good at! Figuring shit like this out! Irwin still says nothing. Yates sighs, lets him go. As Irwin walks up the last few steps, SUNLIGHT shoots out through the crack at the bottom of the door. Irwin stops. YATES (cont'd) What?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Did Wheeler say where I would be taken?

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Some medical facility at Fort Hood... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  267 268 139.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: The Fort Hood Army Psychiatric Hospital. Standard operating procedure for someone like me. (off Yates’ look) One of our army’s nastier little secrets. If they’ve got a whistleblower or a troublemaker they don’t want to discharge, they send them to Hood, let them pad the halls in paper shoes, doing the thorazine shuffle. (beat) That was the worst part in Hanoi -- the months I was drugged. Worse than the torture. The torture was... hell. But at least you knew what it was. The drugs were... limbo. Limbo is worse. For me at least. I can‘t do that again.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: Good! Then don’t! Think of something! Irwin thinks. A thought comes to him. He gets a wistful look. YATES (cont'd) What?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I... I'm going to need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peretz is watching the door. Winter is on his cell phone, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He just-- Winter and Peretz hear the click of the roof door’s lock. They share a look. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) (into phone) One moment, General. Winter nods to Peretz. Peretz starts toward the door, pul his baton. Winter puts a hand on his revolver. Karen Goldberg  269 270 271 272 140. INT. WINTER’S OFFICE - DAWN 269 Irwin runs into Winter's office. He looks through the rub on the ground, finds something in Winter's shattered disp cases -- a flintlock rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peretz grabs the door handle in one hand, raises his bato in the other. Winter watches Peretz, hand on his gun. He senses somethi out of the corner of his eye. Peretz yanks open the door. YATES is standing just inside the door, hands raised.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant! Peretz turns to see... IRWIN climbing up over the edge of the roof, flintlock in hand. Peretz takes a step toward Irwin. Yates lunges out, grabs Peretz and pulis him back into th stairs. Irwin runs to the door, shuts it. He jams the butt of the flintlock under the door handle and stabs the barrel tip into the pebbled tar of the roof. Irwin turns to Winter a Winter fumbles and pulls his revolver from his holster.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Not quite how you thought this was going to go, is it, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: INT, STAIRS TO ROOF
dialogues.text: Peretz breaks free of Yates’ grasp, moves for the door. Yates grabs Peretz’s legs, pulls him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin walks away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: . COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: What are you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  272 273 274 275 276 141.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Irwin starts unzipping the top of his jumpsuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler is watching through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing, Lee?

dialogues.speaker: . GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: What am I doing? I’m doing your job, Colonel. The sun’s up. It’s time to fly the flag. Irwin pulls the folded FLAG out of his jumpsuit, heads fo the flagpole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yates and Peretz fight a fierce battle in the steep, narr confines of the stairs. Peretz is the better fighter, but Yates is fired up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin gets to the flagpole, flag in hand.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Do you know the history of this facility? Of the fort that stood here before this stockade? Winter gives no response. Irwin starts carefully unfoldin the flag, his back to Winter. GENERAL IRWIN (cont'd) A hundred and fifty years ago, one April Sunday, after the snow had melted, it was overrun by a band of Sioux warriors led by Chief Bright Eagle. The garrison commander, Captain Henry Rice, got approval from the. Chief to run the flag. What the Chief didn’t notice was that Rice ran the flag upside down. When reinforcements arrived -- led by a young lieutenant named George Armstrong Custer -- they saw the inverted flag -- which, as you know, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GENERAL IRWIN (cont'd) is the army’s universal sign of distress -- and hightailed it the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yates and Peretz are grappling. They fall off balance and tumble down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin unfolds the last fold in the flag.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: You're forgetting the rest of the story, Mr. Irwin. Custer came back with a division and slaughtered the Sioux.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: (turns to Winter) True.. But you see, in Custer's day, there weren't any TV news crews out beyond the fence with their astounding long lens cameras. Irwin nods his head. Winter looks. HIS POV: Beyond Wheele and his men there are TV newsvans, cameramen standing on top. Irwin turns back to the flag and flagpole. GENERAL IRWIN (cont'd) I don't know if they can see you or me too clearly from there, but they will certainly be able to see the flag. Especially if it’s upside- down. I guarantee you an upside- down flag at this facility would make the cover of Time magazine on Monday morning. If it does, I can also guarantee you that by Tuesday nine a.m. you’ll be on administrative leave and never heard from again. Winter points his revolver at Irwin, cocks the hammer bac

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Let go of the flag. Irwin looks back at Winter and his gun. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goidberg  278 143.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: You know, normally I’d be afraid of someone pointing a large calibre pistol at my back. But I know you, Colonel. You never do your own killing. {nods at gun) Put it down before you embarrass yourself any further. Irwin turns his back on Winter. He Snaps the first of two hooks onto the flag. Winter is shaking with rage. And it looks like he might actually pull the trigger. Then WHAM! Someone bangs against the inside of the roof door. The ti of the flintlock slips an inch in the roof tar. Winter, gun still trained on Irwin, moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Peretz?

dialogues.speaker: LT. PERETZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Lucky you. Winter kicks the rifle away from the door. Peretz steps out, bleeding from the head, extremely pissed-off.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, stop him from raising the flag if you would. Peretz sneers and starts toward Irwin, pulling his baton. Suddenly YATES sprints out from the stairs and dives into Peretz. They slam to the roof.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: Get ready to salute, Colonel. Irwin turns back to the flagpole. He Snaps the second cli onte the flag, He grabs the line. BANG! He stumbles forward. : Winter holds his revolver. Smoke curls out of the barrel. There’s a spreading red stain on the back of Irwin’s unif Irwin has an odd look on his face -- surprise, but relief too, and a certain satisfaction. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Goldberg  278 279 280 281 282 144.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He falls forward, his hand still clutching the flagpole l THE FLAG runs up a few feet. It's spattered with blood -- and it’s rightside-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler has been watching through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dellwo, Cyrus and the others are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DELLWO
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter stands there, jaw open. Yates and Peretz look at Winter in shock and horror. Yate lets go of Peretz, gets off him, goes to Irwin.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WINTER
dialogues.text: (to Peretz) We... we can say he was lunging at me... I was in danger... Peretz turns away, goes to Irwin. He and Yates roll him over. Irwin is alive, barely. A_cell phone rings. Peretz looks at Winter. e in. Winter doesn’t seem to recognize that it's his. Peretz stands, stares at him. Winter snaps out of it, answers the phone. COLONEL WINTER (cont'd) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler is on his cell phone with Winter.

dialogues.speaker: LT. GEN. WHEELER
dialogues.text: Ed, don’t touch anything. And don’t move. We can see you. PULL BACK to reveal THREE SNIPERS, scopes trained on Wint Karen Goldberg  145.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yates kneels beside Irwin. ‘

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: This was it? This was your great plan?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: I was hoping his aim wouldn’t be so good. Yates smiles. Then tears come.

dialogues.speaker: YATES
dialogues.text: General, I’m going to tell them, you know. I don’t care what you say. I’m going to tell them all you saved their lives.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL IRWIN
dialogues.text: On the contrary, Captain. They saved mine. Irwin's eyes cloud over and he’s gone. Yates remains knee beside him. Peretz starts pulling the flag to the top of the pole. Winter looks down at the pistol in his hand, like he'd forgotten it was there. He drops his arm to his side. The gun falls from his hand. He stands there, completely alon and utterly lost. When Peretz gets the flag halfway up, he stops, ties it o FADE TO BLACK. Karen Goldberg
